title: About Me
text:
Hi! My name is Maeve Horan-Portelance, and I am a fourth-year undergraduate student at UCLA, majoring in Statistics and Data Science with minors in Global Health and Film, Television, and Digital Media.
I am interested in data analytics across multiple disciplines, including healthcare, business intelligence, and media analytics. My background combines quantitative problem-solving with creative storytelling, allowing me to analyze complex data while communicating meaningful insights.
I have experience in data analysis, regression modeling, machine learning, data visualization, and database management. My technical skills include R, Python, C++, SQL, Snowflake, Tableau, and MicroStrategy. I have had several opportunitites to apply these skills in a professional setting, the most recent being my Decision Science internship at Travelers Insurance, where I played a key role in evaluating the efficiency of alternate quote campaigns used in a backend model during the sale of insurance. My work involved leveraging SQL, Excel, and R to analyze large-scale datasets and drive data-informed recommendations.
Outside of school and work, I enjoy dancingâ€“after 15 years of competitive dance, I joined UCLAâ€™s Icarus Contemporary Dance Company, for which I currently serve as Finance Director (June 2023 - present), as well as choreograph and perform. I also enjoy playing the piano and drums, creative writing and screenwriting, running, hiking, and exploring LA!

title: Choreography Projects
text:
Pyramids
Pyramids is an original contemporary dance piece choreographed by Maeve Horan-Portelance and performed as part of Icarus Contemporary Dance Companyâ€™s annual Spring showcase, SOL on May 22nd, 2024. The piece explores themes of structure, transformation, and resilience, using movement to symbolize the balance between strength and fluidity. It features 13 members of Icarus Contemporary Dance Company (2023-24).
Performance Date: May 22, 2024

The piece showcases high-energy, commercial jazz with fast footwork, dynamic formations, and musicality-driven movement. It features all 24 members of Icarus Contemporary Dance Company (2024-25).

title: Exploring the Impact of Different Music Types on Heart Rate
text:
Project Overview
This study examines the effect of different music genres on heart rate, focusing on classical music, heavy metal, and a control group (no music). Additionally, we explore the role of listening duration (10 minutes vs.Â 20 minutes) in affecting heart rate changes.
ðŸ“„ Download Full Report (PDF)



Research Questions

Does the type of music (classical vs.Â heavy metal) significantly impact heart rate?

Based on previous research, classical music is expected to lower heart rate, while heavy metal is expected to increase it.

Does listening duration (10 vs.Â 20 minutes) amplify the effect on heart rate?

Prior studies suggest that longer exposure may enhance the physiological response to music.





Methods

Study Design

Two-Factor Blocked Experiment:

Factor 1: Music Type (Classical, Heavy Metal, Control)

Factor 2: Listening Duration (10 minutes vs.Â 20 minutes)


Blocking Variable: Gender (to remove variability in resting heart rates).

Response Variable: Change in heart rate (bpm before vs.Â after treatment).



Participants

144 participants from Bonne SantÃ© Island, evenly split by gender.

Randomly assigned to one of six treatment groups (music type Ã— duration).



Data Collection & Preprocessing

Heart rate measured immediately before and after listening to assigned music.

Boxplots and scatterplots used for initial exploratory data analysis (EDA).

Missing data imputed using appropriate statistical techniques.





Results

Key Findings

Music type significantly affects heart rate (p < 0.001).

Heavy metal increases heart rate significantly compared to both control and classical.

No significant difference between classical and control.

Listening duration has a small but significant effect (p = 0.021).

20-minute listening sessions produced greater heart rate changes than 10-minute sessions.

No significant interaction between music type and listening duration (p = 0.18).



Statistical Analysis

ANOVA Results:

Music Type: p < 0.001 (Significant)

Listening Duration: p = 0.021 (Moderately significant)

Gender: p = 0.066 (Marginal significance)

Interaction Term: p = 0.179 (Not significant)

Post-Hoc Tukey HSD Test confirmed:

Significant difference between heavy metal vs.Â classical (p < 0.001).

No significant difference between classical vs.Â control (p = 0.89).

Diagnostic Plots revealed two outliers, which were removed for final analysis.





Discussion

Heavy metal significantly increases heart rate, while classical music does not lower heart rate relative to the control.

Longer listening durations slightly increase the heart rate effect but do not change the direction of the impact.

Gender was a significant blocking factor, confirming that male and female participants have different baseline heart rates.


Limitations

Participants were not randomly selected, limiting external validity.

Limited to two music genres; future studies should examine additional genres (pop, EDM, country, etc.).

Sample size could be increased to improve statistical power.



Future Research

How do different music genres affect other physiological factors (e.g., blood pressure, mood)?

Can music influence concentration and academic performance while studying?

Is there a connection between music preferences and mental health?





Attachments
ðŸ“„ Full Report (PDF)
ðŸ“Š R Code & Data available upon request.



References

Baker, F., & Bor, W. Can Music Preference Indicate Mental Health Status in Young People? Australas Psychiatry, 2008.

Darki, C. et al.Â The Effect of Classical Music on Heart Rate, Blood Pressure, and Mood. Cureus, 2022.

Kumar, N. The Effect of Listening to Music on Concentration and Academic Performance of Students. 2016.

Roque, A. et al.Â The Effects of Auditory Stimulation with Music on Heart Rate Variability in Healthy Women. 2013.

Sills, D. Does Music Directly Affect a Personâ€™s Heart Rate? Medical Education Faculty Publications, 2015.

title: Predicting Alcoholic Status Using Vitals
text:
Project Overview
This project aims to develop a machine learning model to predict whether an individual is an alcoholic or non-alcoholic based on vital health statistics. The dataset, collected by the National Health Insurance Service in Korea, contains 26 predictor variables, including age, weight, hemoglobin levels, smoking status, and more.
We implemented several classification models and feature selection techniques to improve predictive performance. Our best model, an XGBoost classifier with Hmisc imputation, achieved a Kaggle score of 0.7315, in the top 20 on the class leaderboard.
ðŸ“„ Download Full Report (PDF)



Methods

Dataset and Preprocessing

Data sourced from the National Health Insurance Service in Korea.
Features include demographic, behavioral, and biological markers.
Applied missing value imputation due to ~7% missing values in most predictors.
Conducted Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) using ggplot2 in R.



Missing Value Imputation
We tested three different missing data imputation techniques:
- MICE (Multivariate Imputation by Chained Equations)
- Hmisc (Harrell Miscellaneous) imputation
- Amelia imputation (multiple imputation assuming normality)
Final imputed dataset was selected based on cross-validation accuracy.


Model Selection
We tested multiple models to find the best-performing classifier:
- Random Forest: Kaggle Score of 0.7294
- Logistic Regression: Kaggle Score of 0.7236
- XGBoost (Final Model): Kaggle Score of 0.7315 (Best Performing Model)
We optimized the XGBoost model using:
- Gradient boosting techniques
- Feature importance scoring
- Hyperparameter tuning (learning rate, max depth, and tree count)




Key Findings

Smoking status and hemoglobin levels were strong predictors of alcohol status.

Absences had a significant correlation with alcohol consumption.

Hmisc imputation improved predictive accuracy compared to MICE and Amelia.

XGBoost outperformed all other models, making it the most reliable for classification.

Gradient Boosting models provided better feature importance insights than simpler regression-based models.




Conclusion
This project demonstrated the potential of machine learning in public health analytics, particularly in predicting alcohol consumption behavior based on physiological markers.
Future research could explore:
- Additional predictors (e.g., mental health, dietary factors).
- Refinement of feature selection methods to improve classification accuracy.
- Deep learning approaches for better feature extraction.



Attachments
ðŸ“„ Full Report (PDF)
ðŸ“Š R Code & Data available upon request.



References

Almohalwas, Akram Mousa. Predicting Alcoholic Status Using Personâ€™s Vitals Data Set for Predictive Analysis.

World Health Organization (WHO). Alcohol and Public Health Statistics (2022).

Kaggle Dataset: National Health Insurance Service Korea

title: High School Academic Performance Analysis
text:
Project Overview
This project explores how demographic, familial, and behavioral factors influence high school student academic performance. Using a dataset sourced from Kaggle, we analyzed predictors such as age, gender, parental education, study habits, extracurricular involvement, and absences to determine their impact on GPA.
The primary objective was to train and evaluate a multinomial logistic regression model to classify students into three GPA categories:
- Low GPA: (< 2.5)
- Medium GPA: (2.5 - 3.0)
- High GPA: (> 3.0)
Our analysis included feature selection, model validation, and cross-validation to improve predictive performance.
ðŸ“„ Download Full Report (PDF)



Methods

Dataset and Feature Engineering.

The dataset consists of high school student profiles, including demographic, academic, and extracurricular data.

We removed highly correlated variables using Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) analysis.

The final model included the following predictors:

Behavioral factors: Study time, absences, tutoring, and extracurricular activities.
Demographic factors: Age, gender, ethnicity, and parental education.




Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA)

Visualized GPA distribution across age groups, gender, and ethnicity.
Examined correlations between study habits, parental involvement, and GPA.
Boxplots and scatterplots were used to assess trends in study time and absenteeism.



Multinomial Logistic Regression Model

Implemented multinomial logistic regression to classify GPA into three categories.
Odds ratios were calculated to interpret predictor significance.
Cross-validation (10-fold and LOOCV) was used to validate model performance.
Compared results using Random Forest variable importance analysis.





Key Findings

Demographic factors (age, gender, ethnicity) had little effect on GPA, suggesting that behavioral factors are stronger predictors of academic performance.
Absences had a strong negative correlation with GPAâ€”students with frequent absences were significantly more likely to fall into the low GPA category.
Study time and tutoring were positively associated with GPA, with students who received tutoring being over 13 times more likely to achieve a high GPA.
Extracurricular activities, sports, and music participation were linked to higher GPA, with students in multiple activities performing better academically.
Cross-validation showed high model accuracy (~87%), indicating that our model generalizes well.




Conclusion
Our analysis highlights the importance of study habits, tutoring, and extracurricular involvement in predicting student success. Schools should: - Implement structured academic support programs to help struggling students. - Encourage active participation in extracurricular activities. - Develop attendance incentive programs to reduce absenteeism.
Despite some limitations (such as dataset imbalance), this model provides valuable insights into academic performance predictors, helping educators and policymakers design data-driven interventions.



Attachments
ðŸ“„ Full Report (PDF)
ðŸ“Š R Code & Data available upon request.



References

Kaggle Student Performance Dataset

Gelman, A. & Hill, J. Data Analysis Using Regression and Multilevel/Hierarchical Models

James, G. et al.Â An Introduction to Statistical Learning

title: Bayesian Logistic Regression
text:
Project Overview
This project explores the Bayesian approach to logistic regression, focusing on its theoretical foundations, practical applications, and comparison to frequentist methods. The analysis uses data from the National Institute of Diabetes, which predicts the onset of diabetes in Pima Indians based on diagnostic measures such as BMI, glucose levels, blood pressure, insulin levels, and family history.
We tested four key research areas:
1. Performance comparison between Bayesian and frequentist logistic models.
2. Accuracy assessment of MICE vs.Â BRMS imputation for missing values.
3. Impact of prior selection (Horseshoe vs.Â Laplace) on Bayesian regression.
4. Effect of adding interaction terms on predictive performance.
ðŸ“„ Download Full Report (PDF)



Methods

Frequentist Approach

Used Generalized Linear Models (GLM) for logistic regression.
Handled missing data using MICE (Multiple Imputation by Chained Equations).
Evaluated model accuracy using confusion matrices, precision, recall, and AUC scores.



Bayesian Approach

Implemented Bayesian logistic regression using the brms package in R.
Imputed missing data using both MICE and BRMS-native imputation.
Explored the impact of different sparsity priors:

Horseshoe Prior: Encourages sparsity and shrinks unimportant coefficients.
Laplace Prior: Applies uniform shrinkage to coefficients.

Used Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) sampling for posterior estimation.
Compared model performance using posterior distributions, trace plots, and WAIC/AUC scores.





Key Findings

Bayesian models outperformed frequentist models in most cases but were computationally more intensive.
BRMS imputation handled missing data more effectively than MICE, leading to higher predictive accuracy.
Laplace priors slightly outperformed horseshoe priors in this dataset, improving accuracy by over 2%.
Adding interaction terms did not always improve model performance, and in some cases led to overfitting.
Frequentist models remained more interpretable and easier to communicate compared to Bayesian methods.




Conclusion
This analysis demonstrated the advantages of Bayesian logistic regression, particularly in handling missing data and incorporating prior knowledge. However, computational complexity and the influence of prior selection remain challenges. In contrast, frequentist models provided a simpler, more intuitive approach that still achieved strong predictive performance.
Future work could explore:
- Cross-validation methods to ensure model robustness.
- Alternative prior distributions for Bayesian models.
- More complex interaction terms to capture hidden relationships.



Attachments
ðŸ“„ Full Report (PDF)
ðŸ“Š R Code & Data available upon request.



References

Johnson, A. & Ott, M. Introduction to Applied Bayesian Modeling. CRC Press, 2021.

BÃ¼rkner, P. Handle Missing Values with BRMS. CRAN-R, 2024.

Lukman, P.A. Bayesian Logistic Regression for Hypothyroid Prediction. Journal of Physics, 2018.

Oâ€™Brien, S. & Dunson, D. Bayesian Multivariate Logistic Regression. Biometrics, 2004.

title: Maeve Horan-Portelance
text:
Maeve Horan-Portelance is an undergraduate student at UCLA studying Statistics and Data Science with minors in Global Health and Film, TV and Digital Media. She has a strong interest in data analytics and enjoys combining her quantitative skills and creative abilities to solve complex problems.
She has both work and educational experience in data analysis, experimental design, data mining, statistical modeling, and machine learning. She is proficient in R, Python, C++, SQL, Tableau and MicroStrategy.
